Award.AwardTitle: GOALI/Collaborative Research: Advancing System Reliability with Application to Light-Framed Structures

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative Grant Opportunities for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) project seeks transformation of structural design practice for buildings from one based on the safety and reliability of the individual pieces (components) of a building to one based on the safety and reliability of building's structural systems: roof, walls, and floors. This change in design practice has the potential to lead to both safer and more economically efficient buildings. Buildings framed from cold-formed steel are targeted for initial application. The industry partner, the American Iron and Steel Institute, is a consortium of the nation's steel producers and spearheads the development of codes and standards for buildings designed from cold-formed steel. The industry partner will work directly with the academic research team to insure that industry is utilizing the latest research findings in system reliability, and to insure the research has maximum impact on the practical design of cold-formed steel buildings. The research combines new analytical models for system reliability, with new frameworks for implementing reliability in building design, along with a series of physical tests on cold-formed steel framed walls, floors, and roof trusses - all specifically design to demonstrate how component and system reliability of buildings interact.

The principal goal of this research is to provide a path to transformation of structural design from a component-based process to a system-based process that can be made accessible to design engineers through design code modifications, but which is based on rigorous analysis. Specific research objectives are: (1) enumeration of a general system-subsystem-component hierarchy; (2) development of a subsystem-component reliability procedure supported by experiments and high fidelity simulations; and (3) application of subsystem dependent component reliabilities for codes and standards. The projected solution will identify the primary subsystems that make up a structural system and then employ optimization to define appropriate component reliabilities to ensure a target system reliability and favorable failure mode. Novel reliability-sensitivity analysis and structural simulation enable the optimization engine. The research objectives will be integrated with educational and outreach initiatives, including regular meetings with an Industry Advisory Board.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research developed new methodologies to design structural systems calibrated to meet system performance objectives and reliability goals instead of component safety quantifications used traditionally in structural engineering. The probabilistic methodologies developed can find general application for various material types (concrete, hot-rolled steel, composite), structural systems (bridges, airports) and engineering systems (transportation, electrical) to enable designs for target system reliabilities.

Specific application was made towards light-framed building systems consisting of cold-formed steel (CFS) framing members with wood (oriented strand board, ply or gypsum) sheathing. The system-level reliability quantifications ensure that each structural subsystem – walls, floors and roof trusses – behaves adequately and link up with one another such that the overall building system provides expected performance and reliability under gravity and lateral loads, and especially during seismic events where structures are typically stressed beyond behavior limits which are well established by experiment and analysis.

            Full-scale experiments were performed on floor diaphragm systems under earthquake-type motions and roof truss subsystems under gravity loading. These results were used in conjunction with component-level screw-fastened connections, quarter-scale floor and roof diaphragms, shear walls and full-scale building experiments from other recent projects to develop and calibrate state-of-the-art ‘finite-element’ computer models for each subsystem. The models offer the capability to explore structural configurations for which experimental data is not available, faster and at lower costs. Crucially for the purposes of this project, the models also include the uncertainties in structural properties and external demands so that system failure probabilities can be calculated. Finally, the combined experimental, modeling and probabilistic analysis offer the capability to design structural systems for pre-defined system reliability goals, for instance, a 0.2% in 50 year failure probability used in the design of new seismic systems. These design changes are anticipated to be included in the next generations of CFS seismic design standards by the American Iron and Steel Institute (AISI S400).

The project also offered training and mentoring to several undergraduate, masters and PhD students through a unique combination of expertise from academia and industry.
